Private Litigation Case Title: Sherrill v. Premera Blue Cross et al

Description: Premera Blue Cross agreed to pay $10 million as part of the settlement of multistate litigation stemming from a data breach involving more than 10 million persons.
Agency: Multistate Attorneys General Case

Company: LifeWise, A Premera Health Plan, Inc.
Agency: Oregon Division of Financial Regulation

Company: LifeWise Health Plan of Oregon Inc.
Agency: Oregon Division of Financial Regulation
Oregon Division of Financial Regulation

RCW 48.44.166; RCW 48.44.160; WAC 284-43-1015(2)

Description: Fine levied for failing to mail out renewal notices for several of its individual health plans prior to the first day of annual open enrollment for the following plan year, which was November 1, 2015, as required under 45 CFR ?147.106(f)(1). WAC 284-43-0140.
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: $40,000 fine levied for publishing incorrect provider directories for use by its enrollees, thereby violating RCW 48.44.110; RCW 48.43.510(1).

Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: $25,000 fine levied for misclassifying 5 appeals and failing to provide the IRO with records, documents, or information relevant to the Independent Review within 3 business days in 31 instances. RCW 48.43.535(4).
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: $50,000 fine levied for misclassifying 12 appeals and failing to provide the IRO with records, documents, or information relevant to the Independent Review within 3 business days in 59 instances. RCW 48.43.535(4).
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: $5,000 fine levied for selling a large group negotiated health plan to an ineligible small group. WAC 284-43-6560(4).
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: $50,000 fine levied with compliance and reporting requirements for failing to timely provide decisions on 447 preauthorization requests, erroneously classifying an appeal as a full overturn rather than partial, resulting in the consumer not being provided with an explanation of her rights to seek re...
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: $100,000 fine levied with compliance and reporting requirements for failing to timely provide decisions on 5,053 preauthorization requests, for failing to timely respond to an inquiry of the Insurance Commissioner, for misclassifying two (2) appeals and failing to provide the IRO with records
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: $25,000 fine levied for selling an association health plan, covering 174 insureds, to a business that did not meet the requirements to be issued such a plan.
Agency: Washington State Office of the Insurance Commissioner

Description: Premera Blue Cross agreed to pay $6.85 million to the Office for Civil Rights and to implement a corrective action plan to settle potential violations of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) Privacy and Security Rules related to a breach affecting over 10.4 million people.
Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office for Civil Rights

Description: Under the Settlement, Premera has agreed to establish a $32 million Qualified Settlement Fund to (1) pay for credit monitoring services and identity theft insurance, (2) provide cash payments to Class Members for reimbursement of certain documented out-of-pocket losses and up to $20 per hour for up to twenty hours for time spent addressing or remedying issues plausibly traceable to the Security Incident, (3) provide cash payments of up to $50 as alternative settlement compensation to Class Members who do not make claims for out-of-pocket losses, (4) provide cash payments of up to $50 to qualifying Class Members as compensation under the California Confidentiality of Medical Information Act ("CMIA"), and (5) pay for the costs of the settlement administration, court-approved attorneys' fees and expenses, and service awards for named Plaintiffs. In addition, Premera has agreed to spend $42 million over the next three years on enhanced security measures.
Private Litigation Case Title: Imbler et al v. Premera Blue Cross
